summary: This document is an email chain from October 2020, with earlier threads dating back to 2019, concerning the coordination and transfer of investigative materials (scanned documents and CDs) related to the Epstein investigation between the FBI's Litigation Support Unit and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York. It discusses the status of scanning and transmitting records, including a query about how CDs from Florida were handled.

persons.name: Paul Byrne
persons.context: Copied on email chains regarding the coordination and transfer of Epstein investigation materials between the FBI and the U.S. Attorney's Office.

events.title: Initial Coordination on Epstein Records
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney from SDNY follows up on a conversation, providing contact information and offering to assist the FBI with questions regarding Epstein investigation records.

events.title: Follow-up on Record Scanning
events.description: A follow-up email inquires about the status of scanning and transmitting Epstein investigation records, specifically whether 16,000 or 29,000 pages were sent and requests an index of materials.

events.title: Inquiry about Florida CDs
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office inquires how the FBI's office handled CDs found in boxes of materials from Florida, referencing an attached file that looks like a photocopy of a CD.

events.title: FBI Response on Media Processing
events.description: An FBI Unit Chief from the Litigation Support Unit responds, apologizing for the delay and stating they are looking into the matter, awaiting a response from the FOIA team that processes media.

keyFacts: The email chain reveals ongoing coordination in 2019-2020 between the FBI and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the transfer and processing of Epstein investigation materials.
Specific mention is made of materials originating from Florida, including CDs that required processing.
The FBI's Litigation Support Unit and FOIA team were involved in handling media (like CDs) related to the case.
The correspondence indicates the scale of the records, referencing batches of 16,000 and 29,000 pages that needed to be scanned and transmitted.
NYPD Officer Paul Byrne is consistently copied on these investigative coordination emails.
